userreviews.userReview: Gertrude and Toby's Friday Adventure (Gertrude and Toby #1) By Shari Tharp is a delightful tale for kids about two animal friends that explore on Fridays when the farmer is not around. They sneak to the candy story but meet interesting people along the way then have to accomplish something to get home. A cute story with excellent illustrations. The illustrations really make the story. Running away when not supervised is probably not a good lesson but as long as it is a story... Cute book.

3.5 stars*I received a free copy in exchange for an honest review*Awww when I read this back in 2016, I wasn't really into children books, or either graphic novels, so it kind of took me by surprise.Even tho, I really enjoyed this book. We follow a tortoise named Toby and a goat whose name is Gertrude. (Pretty funny names, huh?). So, they live in this farm and some day they decide to go and visit a candy store. At the end they realize that maybe leaving the farm has been one of the most exciting things they could have done ever.I loved the art. It was really cute and it reminded me of some books that I read when I was a child. I recommend it to anyone, it doesn't matter your age, I think you'll enjoy this baby. Also, it's a really fast read so it's perfect if you're looking for something to read quickly.I'm really looking forward to read the second and third book of this series.

Gertrude and Toby are unlikely friends. They live on McFarland Farms and decide to head to town for an adventure. The adventure starts as they run into some hilarious fairy tale characters on the way. Frog princesses, wicked witches, Gingerbread man, Jack of Beanstalk fame to name a few. Trouble ensues when they are charged with trying to take candy without paying in town and it's up to Gertrude to find help to save Toby. The book was delightful and full of surprises. Wonderful illustrations add to both the humor. Parents should enjoy reading this one with the kids, as well.

What a fun read! I loved the behhhing goat named Gertrude and the wise old tortoise named Toby. There are references to the stories "Little Red Riding Hood", "The Frog Prince", "Snow White", "Jack and the Beanstalk" and "The Gingerbread Man". Gertrude and Toby's Friday Adventure is a great stand-alone story even if a child doesn't have knowledge of the other fairy tales.Since reading this book, I have found that Shari Tharp has also published  Gertrude and Toby Save the Gingerbread Man and Gertrude and Toby Meet the Wolf. I plan to buy all three from Amazon and have them sent to my grand-kids. I am disappointed that I can't find the books to order from Follett. I would love to purchase all three in hardbound for some of my library customers at school. I will keep checking back and hope that they become available. Jim Heath has created comical and colorful illustrations that add humor to this story. Shari Tharp has created a rollicking adventure. I think kids will love it.

Gertrude the goat and her best friend Toby the tortoise are adventurers. No sitting around on the boring farm for them! They love to explore, and every Friday they sneak off the farm for some extra fun.This is a great introduction to this series. In this book the friends briefly meet up with several fairytale characters such as Red Riding Hood, Jack, the Wicked Witch and more. They head to Bay Hale town to get sweets and unbeknownst to them, they actually steal them. When the owner keeps Toby as a hostage while Gertrude finds the money to pay for the sweets, Gertrude sets a chain reaction in place. Kids will enjoy this book and its comical series of events. The illustrations are very simple, but assist in the telling of the story. A good book for school, class and public libraries.I received a copy of this book from the publisher via Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.

I read this with my five year old daughter and eight year old son and they really enjoyed it. They laughed and laughed at the story and the characters and especially liked the drawings. They were talking about all the fairy tale connections for several minutes after I finished the story and will likely dream about this book too. Loved it!I received a free ebook for an honest review.
Cutest story of friends on an adventure. Characters are well developed and have great traits.

A fun and entertaining story for young children that will take Gertrude the goat and Toby the turtle on an adventure. The story will have them meeting characters from well-known stories and how in the process, they help out others. I won a copy of this book during a Goodreads giveaway and I am under no obligation to write a review and do so voluntarily. Gertrude and Toby's Friday AdventureWritten by: Shari TharpIllustrated by: Jim HeathI received an e-ARC of this book from NetGalley and Atlas Publishing in exchange for my honest review.I loved this charming little book! It is perfect for young readers who have already mastered the traditional fairy tales (around age 6 or 7 and up). Young people of this age like to play around with familiar stories and give them a twist. You can develop this by encouraging funny or goofy renderings of familiar songs. They love this sort of game! This skill is exactly what Ms. Tharp develops in her first book in a new series. It is an enchanting mashup of multiple fairytales. Plot:The story is about a young goat (Gertrude) and turtle (Toby) who are best friends and have adventures together. Friday is their day for doing something "big". One Friday they decide to go to the Hay Bale Market for goodies/ candy. Along the way, the friends encounter several familiar fairy tale people (Red Riding Hood, the Wicked Witch, Jack and the Beanstalk, etc.). The author never gives their full names. The reader receives clues such as "girl wearing a red hood" or a witch with dangerous apples. I know that children will be so tickled with themselves when they discover the character names for themselves. Gertrude and Toby's eventually make it to the market but naively don't realize that they must pay for their candy. Young children will certainly sympathize. Toby is kept by the shopkeeper until Gertrude can come up with the funds. She races back down her path and re-encounters all the characters from earlier. They eagerly help our young hero. There is also a lovely little twist at the end which added another layer of fun to the story.Illustrations/ Characters:The illustrations in this book were lovely little water colors in shades of yellow, brown, red, and green. They help flesh out the world and give further visual clues to the story plot. Gertrude and Toby are adorably drawn with human-like faces and large, sweetly innocent eyes. All the characters in the book are drawn with their own personalities. For instance, the shop keeper shows a comical range of facial expressions that convey exactly what is occurring in the book even without words.Overall:I highly recommend this book and can't wait to read the rest of the series.

This is a beautiful book, with a great message for kids. Like a fable, this one has a friendship message at the end that is easy for younger readers to understand but also illustrated the importance to listen to others’ problems and how everyone can ask for help when needed. I read it to my daughter and she loved the pictures and how the fairy tale characters participated in the rescue of one of the main characters at the end. As a mom I appreciate the team work lesson for my little one. Something all children’s book should have. As a reader, I actually find it really entertaining and well written. I’m curious to know about the other adventures from Gertrude and Toby.

Gertrude is a goat and Toby is a tortoise. They are best friends and bored with life on the farm. Together they have adventures that a goat and tortoise would not normally have.This is a cute book with fun illustrations. In fact, the illustrations were my favorite part of the book. The story line had the duo going to Honey Bale Market. On their way the meet up with characters from fairy tales. Their interaction with them is brief. It may be a good way to introduce them to the gingerbread man, the frog princess, Red Riding Hood, Jack, and a few others.

This was a cute story about 2 friends, a goat and a tortoise. I enjoyed the tie in from a bunch of different fairy tales, although it was kind of strange how a few of them were just there and really had no purpose in the story. The illustrations were well drawn and cute as well. Overall, an enjoyable story. I would enjoy reading others in the series
My daughter loved it! I won this book through the goodreads giveaway.

Since I learned to read at age of six, books are my best friends. And nothing gives me more pleasure than reading a good book, not even my favorite sweets, which I usually forget to eat when reading a good book. This book has all the formulas to a great story. But it's not a great one. The main characters are two unexpected friends, a little goat and a young turtle. That's it. The book never explains how such pair become friends and do not tell us why they enjoy so much each other's company but their taste to sweets and their passion for adventure...But if you pass all that, their Friday adventure was really fun. The author takes a nice walk through many known fairytales during this first adventure of the unexpected couple of friends and make you revisit your favorite characters from childhood. I'm sure kids will have fun, although won't ask you to read and read again. And maybe that's a good thing!
I won this book on Goodreads. The children enjoyed and the pictures are nice. It had an interesting play on other fairy tales that went over the children's heads but was fun.
Great book to read to my grandson.he loved it.
This is a wonderful and clever children's tale about a couple of adventurous farm animal friends who take a trip into town. I am looking forward to reading more from this author.

The longer I think about this book, the angrier I get. The first page of this tale is written in present tense, which is unusual for a children's book so it caught my attention. Then, inexplicably, when I turned the page I was transported to the past via verb conjugation but it looked just like the present. This. Is. Not. Allowed. There are Rules! Conventions! Children do not need to be given books that will confuse their ability to properly conjugate, especially given the number of irregular verbs the English language is blessed with.The story and illustrations are perfectly cute but the writing is sloppy and awkward and I would cringe if I ever tried to read it to a child. I was sent this book by the publisher in exchange for my brutally honest review.

Gertrude and Toby are a goat and tortoise with adventure on their minds. In this first installment of the Gertrude and Toby Fairy Tale Adventure series they grab the opportunity of sneaking off to market while the farmer is away. These two (especially Gertrude) think with their stomachs and soon get themselves into trouble when they can't pay for their snacks.This is a delightful tale. I read this to my 5 year old who then point blank refused to sleep until I could promise her I could read the next installment. So many thanks to Netgalley, author and publisher for the opportunity to review this and the next two installments! This is a gentle and amusing tale that I feel could appeal to quite a wide range of ages. It's suggested for 6 - 8 but for a bedtime story it's suitable for younger. The pictures are really well illustrated, they are quite cartoon like but which really appealed to my daughter. The Fairy Tale characters were immediately recognisable before we had read who they were. We're both looking forward to the next installment.

"Gertrude and Toby are best friends and live at McFarland Farms. Every Friday when Farmer Sam goes shopping in town, Gertrude and Toby sneak off the farm for a fun adventure." This is the third book in the Gertrude and Toby Fairy-Tale Adventure Series and the first book that I have read. It is NOT necessary to have read the first book to enjoy the third. Each title works as a stand-alone story.Gertrude is a goat and Toby is a tortoise. They seem to make an unlikely pair, but they work perfectly in the story. In each book the pair go on an adventure and they run into characters from other fairy tales.At first I was skeptical that this concept would come across as fresh and unique, but it definitely does. I loved the fact that the pair head out to go fishing at Trout Lake and they decide that whoever catches the most fish will be the one to choose what adventure they will embark upon. As they are walking a boy runs by on a few separate occasions yelling that a wolf is close by (from the fairy tale "The Boy Who Cried Wolf) and later in the story when a wolf actually does appear, readers meet the pigs from the fairy tale "The Three Little Pigs."The illustrations are simply gorgeous and a treat for the eye. Parents (or Grandparents) will enjoy reading this story to their children just as much as the children will enjoy listening to the tale of the two best friends. I highly recommend this truly wonderful book and I believe that it will make a terrific Christmas gift. Since this book is due to be released in hardcover ten days before Christmas, the timing is perfect. I rate this book as 5 out of 5 Stars and I look forward to reading the first two books in the series as well.I received a free copy of this book from the Publisher through NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. To read more of my reviews, visit my blog at http://AmiesBookReviews.wordpress.com

This was a really fun children's book. I read it with my kids tonight and from my older, more mature children, down to my youngest(5 year old), they all had fun listening to the goofy antics of Toby and Gertrude. They also really enjoyed each fairy tale reference. As we turned the page and a new character would appear it became a race to see who could guess it first(we're not at all competitive in my household). *.* We all enjoyed how Toby and Gertrude weren't your normal farm animals and that they loved to create a little adventure to spice up their farm life of just standing around grazing in the fields. If/when you read it you'll understand that last sentence better. It was fun being introduced to the fairy tale characters in just a little blip and then to have peril come upon our two heroes that they reencountered the fairy tale characters, and together, they all save the day. It was a very clever storyline and one that I'm sure will keep many adventurous and active children engaged in the story and pictures. Probably even causing them to be asking for it to be read again and again. I'm actually really hoping that our local library will carry this one and the other books in the series(if not I will be requesting it and see if they'll be able to). The illustrations were great, my favorite is the page that has Toby and Gertrude racing(just like on the cover) back to the farm. Oh, I also liked the frog princess' kiss page and the Hay Bale Market page and the apple page and the...ok I think if I keep it up I would probably say that I liked all the pages because I really did. Fun illustrations!This is a great book for young or old(which really just means young at heart <333). Perfect book for any storytime and pretty easy reading for most readers past kindergarten.I received a copy from ebooks in exchange for an honest review.Happy Reading!!!

The SkinnyGertrude and Toby aren’t the usual farm animals. They live on MacFarland Farm, but they are the adventurous sort. Every day they get into something new, and Fridays are saved for the biggest adventures when Farmer Sam goes into the city. One particular Friday they decide to go to Hay Bale Market. Along the way, they run into all of the classic characters in the fairy tales: Red Riding Hood, Princess and the Frog, Snow White’s Evil Queen, Jack and the Beantstalk, and the Gingerbread Man.During their adventure to Hay Bale Market, things go horribly wrong when the market owner, Alex, catches Gertrude and Toby stealing! The events that ensue are some of the classic fairy tale endings, and help Gertrude resolve her problem.The Highs and Lows--Illustrations. The illustrations are fabulous. Gertrude and Toby are so cute!--Fairy Tales. How ingenious to incorporate several of the popular fairy tales into Gertrude and Toby’s adventure! At first I thought it was just to help tell the story, but each of these characters is integral to the plot and part of the resolution.--Gertrude and Toby. What great friends! They are like a little old couple, but they are the best of friends and have a ton of fun!The Take-AwayA cute and quick read that incorporates several classic fairy tales in a new and fresh way!Recommendation – Buy, Borrow or Skip? This would be a cute series to start keeping up with, or gift to a young reader.

Gertrude the goat and her best friend Toby are always looking for a new adventure. They especially love Fridays because that is when Farmer Sam went shopping in town. One day, when they see Ryan, Farmer Sam’s son eating goodies and treats they decide that next Friday they are going to sneak into town to get some treats themselves. Along the way they meet a girl in a red cap, a frog princess, an old lady with shiny red apples, and a boy going to sell his cow. Gertrude and Toby find the store with goodies and load up a bag. Unfortunately they didn’t know that they had to pay for the goodies. Toby is held at the store until Gertrude can find some way to pay for the goodies. Thankfully they meet a bunch of great people that are willing to help.This is a great story with wonderful illustrations. Gertrude and Toby are not normal farm animals. They love their adventures and the get a big one. They do have consequences for their actions but I loved how Gertrude was will to do anything to help save Toby. I loved how the people they met along the way were willing to help Gertrude and Toby out.This is a wonderful kid’s story and is the first in a series. I can’t wait to see what happens in the other books.I received Gertrude and Toby’s Friday Adventure for free from eBooks for Review in exchange for an honest review.

I received a free copy of this children's book from the publisher along with another children's book I won in a Goodreads Giveaway. I am providing my honest review in sincere appreciation of the honor.Gertrude and Toby's Friday Adventure features Gertrude the Goat and Toby the tortoise. These good friends live together on a farm and like to sneak away for Friday adventures. On one Friday adventure, they set off to the market for sweets. Along the way they meet interesting new characters who make appearances from the classic fairy tales, such as little Red Riding hood and the wicked witch with her basket of poison apples. These characters are not introduced by name, and it bothered me at first but upon further reflection, I decided that it is really very clever to let the reader figure it out on their own. Most children will recognize the characters and inevitably it will provide the spark for conversation about the classic fairy tale in which they star. If not, the adult will remember and either way, inevitably initiate conversation and hopefully more reading. It's a great idea blending new with the old classics. The illustrations are large, bold, and colorful. I will enjoy reading this book to my grandchildren and I highly recommend it.

This was a beautifully illustrated story for young readers. I enjoyed reading it, and thought it was cute how the author brought in several bits of other fairy tales. Young kids familiar with fairy tales would have a fun time identifying which stories the characters came from. Towards the end, when Gertrude set about trying to rescue Toby, I would have liked the characters from the different fairy tales to have had more of a purpose in getting the story to the ending. Some of them did, but others didn’t, like the magic beans, and the gingerbread man. I’m not entirely sure how those characters helped resolve the conflict. They were just—there. Other than that, I thought the story was cute and fun. Parents and kids who have read fairy tales together would likely enjoy reading this, as it brings several of those fairy tales together.

This is a quick and easy read, and it is also a lot of fun. Gertrude the goat and Toby the tortoise are good friends who enjoy having adventures, and who always save their biggest adventures for Friday, when the farmer is gone for the day and they can sneak off the farm. On this particular Friday they decide to sneak into town to get some candy. They meet some new friends (who may be familiar to the young reader) along the way and when they get into trouble in town, they are able to turn to these friends for help. The illustrations in this book are wonderfully done, and really make the text come alive. The text on each page is minimal, which is perfect for young children with a short attention span. This is a well-written story of friendship and teamwork. I look forward to more adventures with these two friends.

Gertrude and Toby are a goat and a tortoise and are best friends. They like to escape from the farm and have adventures when the farmer is shopping in town. This is a great adventure involving stolen candy, some familiar fairy tale characters and a message of friendship. The illustrations are very well done. My six year old loved it.

A cute little childrens book ideal for 2nd graders. Full of adventure . Gertrude and Toby plan a fun adventure while the farmer is gone and run into lots of different obsticles along the way.A good story about best friends and what they will do for eachother. Great for children.5 stars
Read this with my 3 year old. He loved the pictures and I enjoyed the references to classic story tales. The illustrations are bright, colorful and fun. This is a story we can read again and again.

description: Gertrude the goat and her best friend Toby the tortoise are adventurers. No sitting around on the boring farm for them! They love to explore, and every Friday they sneak off the farm for some extra fun. One Friday, Gertrude and Toby decide to visit the local candy store in town. They discover yummy goodies and treats, but soon find that the treats are not free!? Uh oh! The market owner grabs Toby. He demands money for the candy that Gertrude and Toby have taken by mistake. Gertrude must find a way to save her friend and get back home before Farmer Sam returns.
